text: Cask samples and halfpint @Middle Farm, April 2017. - Naturally sweet stewed pear and drier pear skin aroma made palatable by a semidry touch of wildness and a touch of sweet elderflower syrup, giving it an instant elderflower cordial taste and mouthfeel that worked a treat on this warm spring day. Blossomy elderflower working in accord with the alchohol which remains well hidden and even still a touch watery. Nice peary pun, too. - The Sweet Kentish terroir version of Cantillon Mamouche?
Straw blond with no head. Aroma and flavour have a floral sweetness. Nice flavour.
Pours a very pale blonde colour. Taste is of quire sweet pears. Quite a nice tasting cider

Gravity dispense at Swansea Bay Beer Festival 2016, Brangwyn Hall. As 
Double Vision Impeared Vision, 7.4%.  Pale yellow, clear, still, no head. Aroma is pear peel up front, some cooked chicken, papery. Body is smooth with low carbonation. Taste is pear, papery. light sugars, minerally. Hides the alcohol well but quite plain.

Gravity, 7th Hinckley BF, 11/09/14. Misted green gold without head. Nose edgy mouldering fruit furred with mould. Icing sugar dusted gelatinous pale green flavour with cinnamon dust. Pretty decent. But dangerous.
I´m not used to drink this kind of cider, this feels a lot like fruity juice and still kind off watery. Vinegar aroma.
cask at Egham ... golden yellow ... sweet apple and pear ... dry tanin nose ... very sweet fruit ... juicy pear ... big pear ... maybe some elderflower ... nice juicy and sweet ... tiny sulpher hint

Cask at GBBF 2011, Day 3. Pours hazy yellow. Has a nice, baked pear aroma, faintly spicy. More spice and sugar in the flavor. Very sweet. Medium to full bodied with fine carbonation. Mild warm finish, Christmas-like spices, good sweetness. Very enjoyable.

From a plastic barrel @ GBBF 2011, Great British Beer Festival, Earls Court Exhibition Centre, London, England.Light unclear light to medium yellow colour with virtually no head. Aroma is moderate pear, apples, sweet pear, yellow apples, flour apples - pear, tart. Flavor is heavy sweet and light light acidic with a long duration, tart, dry. Body is medium, texture is watery to oily, carbonation is flat. [20110804]
Cask @ GBBF, 2011. Pours hazy yellow with a small bubbly head. Tart nose an flavor. Barnyard, pear and apples. Dry.

Hazy yellow colour, small head. Aroma is pear, apples, some mild yeasty and wooden notes. Flavour is pear, some yeast, mild vinegar, some alcohol as well as mild apples. The elements in the flavour stick quite well to the aftertaste as well.
Tap @ GBBF. Pours cloudy pale golden with no head. Sour, fruity, acidy aroma. Flavor is sweet, velvety, acidy and alcohol - very nice. Finishes sweet, acidy and fruity.
Cask at GBBF 2011. Pale yellow. Sourish stable aroma. Pear flavor, sourish, apples and grapes.

Box Stillage at the ABC Festival, Altrincham Market 29/08/2010
Fruity aroma. Very light coloured and a little hazy in appearance. Strong in alcohol with a fruity and slightly dry tannin finish.

A Mes rate. Bag in a box at Chelmsford Winter Beer Festival. A pale cleanish yellow (I kid you not...) The aroma is pretty awful and in all honesty smells a bit of poo. The flavour is a dramatic improvement. Really tasty medium sweet pear with a dry fruity finish. A reasonable perry, shame about the aroma.
On tap at Bedford BF ’08. Silvery gold. Slight sourness in the aroma. Sweet, smooth, slightly earthy taste. No perceptible sourness or dryness in the taste: just sweet pears.

From the Barrel at the Croydon Beer Festival. Nose of country farm, cheese and other earthy smells. colour is a lumionous yellow with a green tinge. Medium body. Notes of pear sweetess and a dry finish. Very nice.

Comments: Rather awful example with gross phenols and rubber flavours.

From the barrel, at Reading Beer Festival, April 2006. Hazy straw colour with an apricot tinge - typical perry appearance. Straightforward and fruity. Not too much farmyard or tannins in evidence, although this is a Kentish perry so probably not made entirely from traditional perry pears. Pleasant, easy-drinking and undemanding.
Polypin @ Reading Beer Festival 2006. Slight farmy and nail varnish in aroma. Sweet with a little acidity, a touch of alc in finish.
Reading BF 2006. Sharp fruit aroma. The flavour is soft and fruity. The alcohol is surprisingly well hidden for the percentage, this almost qualifies as juice!
Polypin @ Reading 06: Simple, tasty pears and apples. Sweet yet balanced. Good stuff.
Bag in the box at Reading BF 06. Pale silvery gold colour, no head. Vinegary pear aroma. Fine in mouth. Drinkable. Bit of dryish pear flesh. Not overly alcoholic and only one pound for a half pint.
